style="background: #E0E7EF;" colspan="2" | |- | style="vertical-align: top;" | '''Post Season Series''' || [[Pittsburgh Steelers|PIT]]: 1-0 |- | January 8, 2006 || [[NFL playoffs, 2005-06#AFC: Pittsburgh Steelers 31, Cincinnati Bengals 17|Steelers won 31-17]] |- ! style="background: #E0E7EF;" colspan="2" | Championship Success |- | colspan="2"|'''[[List of Super Bowl champions|Super Bowl Championships]] (6)''' *'''PIT''' (6) â [[Super Bowl IX|1974]], [[Super Bowl X|1975]], [[Super Bowl XIII|1978]], [[Super Bowl XIV|1979]], [[Super Bowl XL|2005]], [[Super Bowl XLIII|2008]] *'''CIN''' (0) â ''None'' '''[[List of National Football League seasons|Conference Championships]] (9)''' *'''PIT''' (7) â [[1974 NFL season|1974]], [[1975 NFL season|1975]], [[1978 NFL season|1978]], [[1979 NFL season|1979]], [[1995 NFL season|1995]], [[2005 NFL season|2005]], [[2008 NFL season|2008]] *'''CIN''' (2) â [[1981 NFL season|1981]], [[1988 NFL season|1988]] '''[[AFC North|Divisional Championships]] (27)''' *'''PIT''' (20) â [[1972 NFL season|1972]], [[1974 NFL season|1974]], [[1975 NFL season|1975]], [[1976 NFL season|1976]], [[1977 NFL season|1977]], [[1978 NFL season|1978]], [[1979 NFL season|1979]], [[1983 NFL season|1983]], [[1984 NFL season|1984]], [[1992 NFL season|1992]], [[1994 NFL season|1994]], [[1995 NFL season|1995]], [[1996 NFL season|1996]], [[1997 NFL season|1997]], [[2001 NFL season|2001]], [[2002 NFL season|2002]], [[2004 NFL season|2004]], [[2007 NFL season|2007]], [[2008 NFL season|2008]], [[2010 NFL season|2010]] *'''CIN''' (7) â [[1970 NFL season|1970]], [[1973 NFL season|1973]], [[1981 NFL season|1981]], [[1988 NFL season|1988]], [[1990 NFL season|1990]], [[2005 NFL season|2005]], [[2009 NFL Season|2009]] |} The '''[[Cincinnati Bengals|Bengals]]-[[Pittsburgh Steelers|Steelers]] rivalry''' is a [[National Football League rivalries|rivalry in the NFL]]. The two teams have played each other twice a year since becoming division rivals in [[1970 NFL season|1970]], the lone exception being [[1982 NFL season|1982]], when the annual matchup in [[Cincinnati, Ohio|Cincinnati]] was canceled due to the [[National Football League Players Association#1982 strike|player's strike]]; the teams only met in Week 2 in [[Pittsburgh]] that season just before the start of the strike. Originally placed in the [[American Football Conference Central Division|AFC Central]] following the [[AFL-NFL merger]], the two teams currently compete in that division's successor, the [[American Football Conference North Division|AFC North]]. The rivalry is not quite as historic as the [[Battle of Ohio (NFL)|Bengals-Browns Rivalry]], however, many Bengals fans consider the Steelers to be their greatest rivals, much like [[Cleveland Browns]] [[Dawg Pound|fans]]. ([[Steeler Nation|Steeler fans]], however, often consider the [[Baltimore Ravens]] as their top rival.) It is disputed which is the more widely bitter rivalry, but this specific rivalry is oftentimes ranked as one of the most bitter rivalries in the NFL, chiefly due to the Steelers having more championships and the events of the 2005 wild card playoff game between the two teams. Though the Steelers have mostly dominated this rivalry, it has heated up in recent seasons due to the Bengals resurgence among NFL teams. Even during the Bengals' dismal years in the 1990s and early 2000s when they were one of the NFL's worst teams, they would at times get the better of the Steelers, who were usually the dominant team in the division during the "Bungals" years. One notable example came in [[1999 NFL season|1999]], when the Bengals swept the Steelers in the season series while finishing 4-12 overall. (Their other two wins came against the Browns, who had returned to the NFL as an [[expansion team]] that season.) The Steelers themselves were going through a rare down year, finishing 6-10 for the season. While the Steelers have a much older rivalry with the Browns and have a longer history against several teams from the [[National Football Conference|NFC]] due to the Steelers being part of the "old" NFL prior to the 1970 merger, the Bengals have met the Steelers more than anyone else in their own history, due to the [[Tennessee Titans]] being moved to the new [[American Football Conference South Division|AFC South]] in the [[2002 NFL season|2002 realignment]], while the Browns missed keeping pace due to [[Cleveland Browns relocation controversy|being out of the league for three years]]. The rivalry has enjoyed a revival since meeting in the playoffs for the first time in the 2005 wild card. During the game, division champion Cincinnati quarterback [[Carson Palmer]] was injured by Steeler [[Kimo von Oelhoffen]]. Palmer's injured ACL and MCL kept him out of the game, which the Steelers won 31-17. After undergoing surgery to repair the damaged ligaments, Palmer was featured in a [[Sports Illustrated]] article focusing on the new technique used to repair his knee. In that article, Palmer is quoted as saying "I hate the Steelers more than I hate UCLA,"{{cite web|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/multimedia/photo_gallery/0605/gallery.palmer/content.1.html SI.com|title=The Rehab of Carson Palmer|work=Sports Illustrated|publisher=SI.com}} a reference to his college days at USC, although Palmer himself did not blame the Steelers for his injury, since his own player blocked von Oelhoffen into him. Many fans from both sides remain bitter about this episode. The Rivalry rose to new heights in 2009 when the Bengals were the Division champions over the Steelers and the rest of the Division. They boasted a perfect 6-0 Division record, not only twice beating the long-time champion Steelers, but also the [[Baltimore Ravens]] and the [[Cleveland Browns]]. Despite their division dominance, the Bengals were only 4-6 against the rest of the NFL. The Bengals made the playoffs as AFC North Champions, and they began their short playoff run with a home game against the [[New York Jets]]. The Bengals were expected to win, but the Jets were able to shut down the Bengals and put an end to their season.. Pittsburgh has a 50-32 series lead against the Bengals. A [[chess set]] is available at many stores of ''Bengals vs. Steelers''. ==1970s (Steelers 14-6)==
